purpose.description: Through engaging content and interactive lessons, Recyclepedia likely aims to inspire younger generations to understand recycling, waste management, and environmental stewardship, making climate-friendly practices

CurbsidePage.title: Curbside Pickup Items
CurbsidePage.subtitle: Find out what you can recycle in {city}

paper.title: Paper
paper.description: Clean and dry newspaper, magazines, catalogs, telephone books, printer paper, copier paper, mail, and all other office paper without wax liners.

cardboard.title: Cardboard
cardboard.description: Packing boxes, cereal boxes, pizza boxes, gift boxes, and corrugated cardboard. Flatten all boxes before placing them in your cart.

cans.title: Cans
cans.description: Steel and aluminum food and beverage cans. Aluminum bottles are also accepted.

cartons.title: Cartons
cartons.description: Aseptic poly-coated drink boxes, juice cartons, and milk cartons.

bottles.title: Bottles (plastic & glass)
bottles.description: Plastic bottles such as milk, water, detergent, soda, and shampoo bottles (flatten and replace the cap); glass bottles.

plasticTubs.title: Plastic tubs and jugs
plasticTubs.description: Plastic tubs, such as butter or yogurt tubs, and plastic jugs, such as milk or detergent jugs.

notListed.message: Can't find what you're looking for?

ItemsPage.title: Find Recycling Locations
ItemsPage.subtitle: Discover where to recycle specific items in your area

search.initialMessage: Enter an item and press "Search" to find recycling locations.

LearnPage.title: Learn About Recycling
LearnPage.subtitle: Explore recycling education and get involved in your community

recyclingTips.title: Recycling Tips
recyclingTips.selectPrompt: Select an item to learn how to recycle it

batteries.name: Batteries
batteries.tip: Batteries should not be thrown in the trash. Take them to a recycling center or battery drop-off location.

ceramics.name: Ceramics
ceramics.tip: Ceramics cannot be recycled with regular glass. Dispose of them in your regular trash.

christmasLights.name: Christmas Lights
christmasLights.tip: Old Christmas lights can be recycled at designated e-waste recycling locations.

foodWaste.name: Food Waste
foodWaste.tip: Food waste can be composted. Some cities also accept food scraps for recycling.

juicePouches.name: Juice Pouches
juicePouches.tip: Juice pouches are not recyclable in most curbside programs. Check with local programs for special disposal.

keurigCup.name: Keurig Cups
keurigCup.tip: Keurig cups (K-Cups) can be recycled if properly separated. Check for a recycling symbol and remove the foil lid.

glass.name: Glass
glass.tip: Glass bottles and jars are usually recyclable, but check if your local recycling program accepts them.

medicine.name: Medicine
medicine.tip: Expired or unused medications should be taken to designated drop-off sites. Do not flush them.

bottles.name: Plastic Bottles
bottles.tip: Plastic bottles are recyclable. Make sure they are clean and free from residue.

packingPeanuts.name: Packing Peanuts
packingPeanuts.tip: Packing peanuts can sometimes be recycled, or you can reuse them.

pizzaBoxes.name: Pizza Boxes
pizzaBoxes.tip: Pizza boxes with grease stains are generally not recyclable. Remove excess grease before recycling.

plasticBags.name: Plastic Bags
plasticBags.tip: Plastic bags should not be placed in curbside recycling. Recycle them at designated collection points.

plasticButterContainers.name: Plastic Butter Containers
plasticButterContainers.tip: Plastic butter containers are usually recyclable if clean.

plasticCups.name: Plastic Cups
plasticCups.tip: Plastic cups are recyclable, but check with your local program for specific guidelines.

plasticPlates.name: Plastic Plates
plasticPlates.tip: Plastic plates are often not recyclable, but some programs may accept them.

plasticUtensils.name: Plastic Utensils
plasticUtensils.tip: Plastic utensils are generally not recyclable, but check your local recycling program.

rubberGloves.name: Rubber Gloves
rubberGloves.tip: Rubber gloves should be discarded in the trash, as they are generally not recyclable.

styrofoam.name: Styrofoam
styrofoam.tip: Styrofoam is not widely recyclable. Some areas offer drop-off locations for recycling.

teaBags.name: Tea Bags
teaBags.tip: Tea bags made from paper can be composted, but those with synthetic materials should be discarded in the trash.

waxPaper.name: Wax Paper
waxPaper.tip: Wax paper is not recyclable in most curbside programs.

wrappingPaper.name: Wrapping Paper
wrappingPaper.tip: Wrapping paper with glitter, foil, or tape is not recyclable. Plain wrapping paper can be recycled.

yogurtCup.name: Yogurt Cups
yogurtCup.tip: Yogurt cups are usually recyclable if clean. Check with your local recycling program.

intro.title: Understanding Recycling
content: Recycling is an essential practice that helps reduce waste, conserve natural resources, and minimize the environmental impact of human activity. By turning materials like plastic, paper, glass, and metals into new products, recycling prevents these items from ending up in landfills, where they can take decades to decompose.

Recycling also helps reduce greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and more. In addition to this, it helps reduce pollution of our environment, water, and air. Ultimately, recycling is an initiative that helps reduce global climate impacts by cutting down greenhouse gas emissions. It benefits our communities, businesses, and the environment by reducing pollution, lowering the demand for raw materials, and creating new job opportunities in recycling industries.

volunteerCleanup.title: Volunteer Clean Up
volunteerCleanup.description: VolunteerCleanup.Org engages volunteers to cleanup their neighborhoods, shorelines, and waterways as a way to raise awareness about marine debris and encourage people to reduce their reliance on single-use plastics.

composting.title: Composting
composting.description:
Composting is the process of turning organic waste into nutrient-rich soil through natural decomposition. It's an eco-friendly way to reduce waste and enrich soil.
Get started with the resource below!

handsOnMiami.title: Hands On Miami
handsOnMiami.description: Become a volunteer & make difference in the community!

videos.recyclingForKids: Recycling for Kids | Learn how to Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle

greenSchools.title: Join the Green Schools Challenge
paragraphs: K-12 students and teachers looking to learn more about waste reduction, energy efficiency, water conservation, and more, join the Green Schools Challenge to have access to full lesson plans to promote environmental stewardship.
This is an initiative to inspire students and teachers to adopt sustainable practices within their schools.
By participating, schools can make a lasting impact on their communities and the planet. Join us today and be part of the change!

ourStory.title: Our Story
ourStory.content: Since 2006, Dream in Green (DIG) has empowered individuals, especially youth, to take a leading role in addressing climate change and other environmental challenges facing South Florida. By assisting schools, households, local governments, and businesses, DIG helps reduce their environmental footprint. Through partnerships within our community, we develop, implement, and oversee educational programs and workshops that promote environmentally sustainable behaviors among all age groups, with a particular emphasis on K-12 students.

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.mainContent: At Dream in Green (DIG), we recognize that contamination is one of the biggest challenges in recycling, occurring when non-recyclable items enter the recycling system. This not only diminishes recycling success rates but also creates confusion among residents regarding acceptable materials in their local programs.
mission.expandedContent1: To address these challenges, our mission is to provide Miami-Dade County residents with accessible and up-to-date recycling information. By offering clear guidance on proper recycling practices, we empower individuals to participate effectively in their community's recycling efforts, ultimately increasing the recovery of recyclables.
mission.expandedContent2: Our platform, Recyclepedia, serves as a comprehensive resource for accurate information on what can be recycled. It helps users understand acceptable items in their municipalities and provides alternative disposal options for those not accepted in their recycling programs. By facilitating proper recycling practices, Recyclepedia contributes to higher recycling rates, reduced pollution, and improved community health.

partners.title: Our Partners
partners.content: DIG was honored to receive the 2021 Innovation Grant from The Children's Trust, which supported the creation of Recyclepedia. This initiative aims to improve recycling, reduce pollution, and enhance community health in Miami-Dade County. DIG collaborates closely with various municipalities, non-profits, and community partners to spread awareness and provide accurate data.
